articles.title: Shishir's Website
articles.description: Some additional details about the website
articles.contents:
Here is my visualizations:
The FIFA22 data set contains all key attributes, and features of male
football players around the world. In this analysis, I focus on major
attributes to see relationship between common variables such as
Potential, wages, Reputation, Value and other player information.
We know that most soccer players tend to be portrayed by social media
as extremely gifted players who can do crazy stunts with their feet. In
today’s analysis, I will focus on debunking this myth that soccer
players actually extremely gifted.
Here
is the analysis of some Player demographics: Height, age, Weight
Using the FIFA 22 data set we get access to some interesting
variables and can conduct detailed analyses. If we were to take a look
at the actual player demographics, we can see whether there may or may
not be a truth to the myth regarding soccer player.









Here we can see the histograms of the distribution of the “Height in
cm”, “Weight in kgs” and “Age” of the players.



What can we learn from each graph?
A = A shows the distribution of age of all the players in the FIFA 22
data set. We can see that centered around the age of 26, with uni modal,
symmetrical shape that appears to be right skewed . There is a fairly
large range for the data with ages ranging from 15 to 40. Most players
do hit their prime in their early 20s so it makes sense that the data is
centered around the age of 22 and with a right skew.
B = B shows that the distribution of weight is actually fairly
normal/symmetrical and unimodal. The center of the data looks to be
around 75kgs with a range between 60 to 90 kgs. This is not surprising
but debunks the myth of how people think players are almost god like. If
we look here we see that most of the players are within the normal range
of weight. No similar to the rest of us. This also makes sense as
defenders tend to need to be more physically built and heavier while
attackers usually need to be quick and hence prefer weigh lesser.
C = C shows that the distribution of height is, again, fairly
normal/symmetrical . The center of the data looks to be around 180 cms
with a range between 160 to 200 cms. However, there is appears to be
bimodal as there seem to be two prominent peaks. This suggests that
players tend to get clustered into two groups of heights and not a lot
of players who are in between the two peaks actually exist. Firstly, we
can see that the height of all the players is similar the average human
height even if it is slightly left-skewed from the world. We can see
here that most players are, in fact, around the average height but there
are also a lot of players who are above the avergae height. This is not
surprising because of the requirements of Defenders and Attackers often
needing to head the boal to protect or score a goal.
Therefore, it is clear that soccer players are similar to humans but
lets actually take a look at how the compare with each other in terms of
their actual attributes.



From these various graphs we can learn a lot about the attributes of
most players: A: This graph is depicting the distribution of pace for
players. It has center of 70 with a range between 40 to 90. This
translates to range of about 12 to 20 seconds to complete a 100 m race.
Most people who are physically fit and healthy can easily run at that
pace. Moreover, the distribution is again unimodal and symmetrical
indicating that a lot of players live within this range. This is again
debunks the myth that soccer players are crazy fast as most players can
actually run at normal speed.
B: This graph is depicting the distribution of dribbling for players.
It has center of 75 with a range between 30 to 90. Moreover, the
distribution is unimodal but left skewed indicating that a lot of
players live within this range. However, this is where we come to see
why soccer players are great. It takes immense practice to be able to
gain the skills of ball control like them and there is still a very
large range inters of players capabilities in handling the situation.
This we cannot speak towards whether we can learn anthing from this
stat.
C: This graph is depicting the distribution physicality and toughness
of players. It has center of 70 with a range between 30 to 90. Moreover,
the distribution is again unimodal but only a slight left skewed. This
is indicating that a lot of players again live within this range,
however, this is where we come to see why soccer players can be
considered crazy again. Even with their normal wight, and height, soccer
players are definately much more physically well-built, tough and
strong.
D: This graph is depicting the distribution of Passing for players.
This arguable most symetrical graph with a center of 60 with a range
from 30 to 90. This graph is unimodal and shows that players do tend to
have higher passing statistics in general but again we can see a large
range here.
E: This graph is depicting the distribution of Physic for players. It
has center of 50 with a range between 30 to 90. Most people who are
physically fit and healthy can easily run at that pace are never able to
achieve this level of physicallity with intense discipline. Moreover,
the distribution is again unimodal and symmetrical indicating that a lot
of players live within this large range. This is again debunks the myth
that soccer players are crazy strong or big as most players can actually
fall all across the range.
F: This graph is depicting the distribution of Defending for players.
This probably the most interesting graph as we see almost a bimodal
relationship with a large range between 10 and 90. This is not
surprising as attackers are usually very bad at defending. So if you
assumed that any soccer player must be amazng at defending, it is only
due to practice and the data shows no specific center.
Thus we can see how there player demographics and understanding of
the distribution of the players attributes can shed light on the false
perception we have about players in sports. In the next section, I will
dive deeper by looking at how these attributes can shed light on some of
the ways in which we can see how players utlize their skills to perform
well in games. Its really an effect of practice and less about raw
phsyical talent.
Understanding wages and
value



If we were to study the above counter map. This map looks at the
interaction of the player attributes of defending and passing. Often
times defenders must be great passers, but as we can see here, great
passers don’t need to be good at defending. This is seen when see that
there are two elevations around (30, 50) and at (60, 60). The passing
attribute is also spread across the map but the defending like in the
distribution we saw earier has almost a bimoal relationship. This means
that being good at passing is essential to becoming better and it’s not
that defenders are automatically good at passing either.



Now when we take a look at this counter map, we can see how pace and
dribbline are quite interelated. There is an elevation at (70, 65) which
is fairly high for players and there seems to be positive trend in the
relationship between these two varibales. We can see that as pace
increasing the dribbling scores also go up with it. This could show the
importance of practice as a lot of soccer drills actually involve speed
training, acceleration, positioning all with the ball. They may be some
level of interaction due to other factors but that does not mean that
soccer players are again very fast and very good at dribbling.
The previous assessment is however quite doubtful so lets look at
some further evidence as to how speed varies across the players
international reputation. From the density graphs below, we can identify
that higher the international reputation, there is likely to be higher
range when a player gets better at football. We can see players that
with a score of 5 (Very reliable) have their peak at a higher pace and
cover a larger range in comparison to player who had a score of 1
(Unreliable). Thus we can see the better players tend to have a higher
pace and also tend to be more reliable when they have a higher pace.
Regardless, we can also still see a large distribution or range for the
pace of players.



Thus we come to an interesting varible to study: The work rate. ork
Rates dictate where players position themselves on the pitch. Also known
as Player Work Rate, it is the rate of a player’s behaviour on the pitch
in terms of attacking and defensive works. The Work Rate is defined for
Attacking (Attacking Work Rate – Abbreviated as AWR) and Defensive
(Defensive Work Rate – Abbreviated as DWR) and rated between low, medium
and high, which defines how a player puts effort to participates in
attacks and defenses even when they are out of position.
A high attacking work rate implies that the player is going to be in
all of your attack moves. With medium, he will select the attack actions
he will join. A player with low attacking work rate will remain in his
position while the team attacks. With the defense, it is exactly the
same but in the opposite direction.
What can we learn from the previous graph from a glance. Most of the
players work rate tend to be highly associated with the normal body
type. As players work rate increase, whether attacking or defending, the
players also seem to have normal weight and a normal body type. Only the
low-low work rate members so a higher level of stocky build while the
leaner players seem to show a higher work rate, be in attacking or at
defending.



Moreover, when we comee back to the assessment of international
repution we can see how well correlated it is with a players potential.
As a player gets older, they are more likely to be given a higher
potential. Each individual in FIFA has a pre-programmed player potential
which determines how fast their attributes should grow and when they
should stop. You can think of it as a player’s predicted or peak overall
rating. This is how we know which players are going to be wonderkids.
While the scatterplot below may show no relationship with the player
value or potential, when we include the color as international
reputation, we can see how player with higher international reputation
tend to be clustered around a higher a higher value and potential. Thus
we can see that although players with lower potential dont possess all
the stats required they will become better as they age and continue to
play better.



We can bring this all together by taking a look at the graph below.
In the scatterplot there are four broad variables being studied. We can
see a positive trend occuring between mental composure and overall
rating. This also consistent with the international reputation and the
work rate of the players as we can see the players international
reputation and work rate increasing with the overall rating.



Thus, I think it is pretty clear that while soccer players may seem
inhuman, they are actually very much similar to most of us. We saw this
when we analyzed the distribution of the players scores when we
considered the background attributes and skills of that soccer players
need. We can also see how training is integral to becoming a better
player by looking at so many variables like age play a role in the
potential of a player. Most soccer players are extremely good and can
possibly be just as good. It is only through training and practice that
these players are capable of getting a higher over all rating and are
mentally strong enough to take on the challenge. Thank you!

articles.description: Welcome to the website. I hope you enjoy it!

            born and brought up in Bangalore, India.
